The home directory is where DocExplore will store all of the data you create.
It is recommended to use the default directory provided below but you may change it if needed.

Press OK to confirm the home directory or cancel to specify it at a later time.

Allows you to set the default settings of the DocExplore software suite.
Create a new book from images
Select image files which make up the pages of a new book. The pages will stay in the order the images were selected but they can be reordered at any time.
Create a single page document from images
Select image files which make up the parts of a single page document. The image configuration will be guessed based on the file names but it can be changed at any time.
From annotation with the field name
A presentation with the same title already exists. Do you want to replace it?
This presentation will be packaged into a file that can be loaded by the DocExplore mobile app.
This presentation will be added to the local collection of this DocExplore installation.

Limiting the dimensions of images serves to lower the hardware requirements of presentations. If you experience excessive loading times or even crashes when viewing a presentation, it is recommended to enable this option. Be aware that although this will not distort the images, it might visibly reduce their quality, especially when zooming in.

Enable this option if some of the pages of the presentation contain areas of transparency, otherwise they will not render properly. Please note that if this option is enabled, the processing time required to complete the export may increase significantly as well as the resulting file sizes.
This presentation will be packaged into an archive suitable for a website.

Do not import regions without annotations

Annotation panel
This panel allows you to view, edit and add metadata associated with the right side document.
Use the icons to add text, image and media annotations.

The left side panel shows the pages of your presentation. To add pages, you can:
 • Click on the ⊕ icon in the toolbar to import images
 • Drag books and pages from the right side panel
 • Drag image files directly from the file explorer

The right side panel shows the local collection from the management tool.

This is your digital collection from the management tool.
← Drag items to the left to include them in your presentation.

Page
The left side panel displays a page of your book.
You can create and modify regions of interest with the toolbar above.

The right side panel contains the annotations associated with this page.
Slide your finger to turn the pages
Tap on a highlighted area to get more information

This panel displays the pages of your presentation. To add pages, you can:
 • Click on the ⊕ sign in the toolbar to browse for images↑
 • Drag books and pages from the right side →
 • Drag images directly from your file explorer into this panel

Book tools

 Navigate back to the collection
 Import images as pages
 Delete the selected pages

This is your digital collection from the management tool.
← Drag items to the left to include them in your presentation.

Cover

Each frame can hold an image representing a part of the book cover. Since book covers often have rounded edges, they might require an image with transparent parts. However, images with transparency can't be efficiently compressed and might not be suitable if exported in certain contexts. You can therefore define opaque and transparent versions of the cover images.
Any cover part that is undefined will be given a default image if exported. You can drag files and images on to these frames to define their content. Use the right click to delete the content of a frame.

Right click on a file to preview contents.
← Drag files to the left to include them in your presentation.
This is your local storage. Double click on a drive to browse contents.

Manual stitching

You can click and drag the parts around the canvas.
The corners of the parts have handles allowing you to resize them.
Press CTRL while moving a handle to rotate the part.
If the parts can't be seamlessly assembled with these manipulations, you can edit the stitches by first selecting a part (the selected part has a yellow outline) and then right clicking on different part. This will open the stitch editor.

Annotation panel

This panel allows you to view, edit and add metadata associated with the right side document.
Use the button to add text, image and media annotations.

Book

This is a book in your collection. From here you can:
 • Use the toolbar to navigate and add or remove pages
 • Drag image files directly from the file explorer to add pages
 • Reorder the pages by dragging the images
 • Manage the book cover

Use the button to change the title.
Modifications are ignored if the book is locked

Collection

This is your local collection. With the toolbar above, you can:
 Import a book poster that was exported from a different collection
 Export the selected book or poster
 Create a new document
 Delete the selected documents

Page

The left side panel displays a page of your book.
You can create and modify regions of interest with the toolbar above.

The right side panel contains the annotations associated with this page.

Poster

This is a poster in your collection. From here you can:
 • Use the toolbar to navigate and edit parts
 • Drag image files directly from the file explorer to add parts
 • Change the configuration by dragging the images

Use the button to change the title.
Modifications are ignored if the poster is locked

This is a slide of your presentation. You can:
 • Create and modify regions of interest with the toolbar above
 • Add regions and annotations by dragging them from the right→
 • Drag supported files on a region from your file explorer

Page tools

 Navigate to the previous page
 Navigate to the next page
 Navigate back to all pages
 Fit the page view to fill the panel
 Create a free shape region of interest
 Create a rectangular region of interest
 Crop the page

Stitching editor
This editor allows you to precisely define the overlap between two images. This is done by specifying pairs of points that match on both documents, referred to as stitches.

Usage
This editor displays the two images that were selected for stitching. You can drag the mouse with the right button held down to move around either image. Use the mouse wheel to zoom in and out. Red dots indicate points of interest that can be used as endpoints for a stitch. Stitches themselves are drawn as pink lines.

Automatic stitching
Stitching can be done automatically by using the  detect button. This process will assume that both images do indeed overlap and will try to force a match.

Manual stitching
You can manually stitch the images if the detection isn't successful. You can create a point of interest by left clicking on one of the images while holding Ctrl key. You can also use one of the automatically detected points of interest. Points can be selected by left clicking on them, showing a yellow outline. When a point is selected on each image, use the  link button to add a stitch between them, or remove a stitch if one already exists.

Toolbar
Here are the tools at your disposal in this editor:
 •  Flip between a horizontal and vertical layout
 •  Reverse image locations
 •  Clear all stitches and show auto-detected points of interest
 •  Clear all stitches and points of interest
 •  Add or remove stitch between selected points
 •  Detect stitches automatically
 •  Leave the editor

Poster stitching

This is a poster being stitched into a seamless document. Use this tool to assemble slightly overlapping images into a single one.

Usage
This editor displays a canvas where all the parts of the poster are laid out. The goal is to assemble them together to construct a single image. You can drag the mouse with the right button held down to move around the canvas. Use the mouse wheel to zoom in and out. You can select individual parts by left clicking on them. Press space when a part is selected to see the contained image in full definition.

Automatic assembly
This process can be done automatically by using the  detect button. If the detection is sucessful, all you need to do is rotate the interlinked parts to best fit inside a rectangle and  render the poster.

Manual assembly
You can manually assemble the parts if the detection isn't successful. You can move a part around by dragging it with the left mouse button. The corners of a part can be grabbed for resizing and rotating (by holding the Ctrl key).
If you grab a part close to an edge, that edge will appear in blue and snap on to nearby edges when dragged, allowing for perfect alignment of parts. Similarily, when resizing a part, the corners adjacent to the corner being dragged will snap on to nearby corners.
When you modify a part, all connected parts (denoted by either a red or blue line) will change as well to remain unchanged relative to the original one. A red line indicates that the connection between two parts is exactly as displayed with no further deformations. A blue line indicates that a more complex deformation has been computed between the two. This is necessary when you have images that don't perfectly line up or overlap, usually due to slighly different perspectives or camera lens deformations.
If a part is selected (yellow outline), you can right click on different part to edit their relation:
 • If no relation exists, you can associate them together. This will build a red line and lock both parts into place relative to each other based on their current configuration.
 • If a relation exists, you can disassociate the parts. No line is shown and changing one has no influence on the other.
 • If a relation exists, you can edit the stitches. This will allow you to define complex deformations to seamlessly join both parts.

Toolbar
Here are the tools at your disposal in this editor:
 •  Save the current state of the stitches
 •  Clear all stitches
 •  Detect document layout and stitching
 •  Use current layout for rendering
 •  Cancel stitching process

Poster rendering
This editor allows you to render a stitched poster. referred to as stitches.

Usage
This editor displays the full layout of your poster. You can drag the mouse with the right button held down to move around either image. Use the mouse wheel to zoom in and out. Four lines define the rectangle that will be rendered, the excluded area being greyed out. You can click and drag these lines to change the rectangle. You can type a numerical value in the Max tile size field to control the number of sub-images that will be created. Use the Resolution slider to control the quality of the output (slide all the way to the right for minimal loss). Once these parameters are set up, use the   render button to generate the poster. Upon completion the editor will close.

Toolbar
Here are the tools at your disposal in this editor:
 •  Fit the bounds around the content
 •  Render the poster
 •  Leave the editor

Poster tools

 Navigate back to the collection
 Append images as poster parts
 Delete the selected parts
 Fill the holes in the poster grid to obtain a rectangle
 Swap all the parts horizontally
 Swap all the parts vertically
 Rotate all the parts a quarter turn counter-clockwise
 Rotate all the parts a quarter turn clockwise
 Stitch together parts that don't line up

Preview
The preview is used to represent this document in the reader tool once exported.
If no preview is defined, a default image is used.
You can drag a file or an image on to this frame to set the preview.
Use a right click on this frame to delete the current preview.

You have selected a region of interest and the elements it contains are displayed in the right panel →
You can add, remove, edit and reorder the elements using the toolbars.
Slide your finger on the right side to scroll up and down
Tap anywhere on the left side to return to the book
Slide your finger to select a book
Tap on a book to open it

Stitch editor

The stitch editor provides tools for stitching together two parts which means finding points of overlap between the two and joining them into a single image.

Would you like to limit the detection to empty assocations (the lines in red)? If you select not to, all current association will be removed and the detection will make no assumptions on the overall layout.
